name: Amoebic Liver Abscess
theory:
Etiology

Caused by Entamoeba histolytica protozoa via the fecal-oral route. Trophozoites invade the colon (flask-shaped ulcers), enter portal circulation, and lodge in the liver causing liquefactive necrosis.

Location

Right Lobe (80%): Due to laminar flow in the portal vein (superior mesenteric vein drains to right lobe).
clinical:
Presentation

Right upper quadrant pain, fever (swinging), tender hepatomegaly. Jaundice is rare.

Anchovy Sauce Pus

Aspiration yields pathognomonic odorless, chocolate-colored fluid (necrotic hepatocytes + blood). Pus is sterile (protozoa are in the wall).
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž Management
Medical: Metronidazole (Flagyl) is the mainstay (highly effective).
Aspiration: Indicated if large, left lobe (risk of pericardial rupture), or failure of medical therapy.

name: Gastric Outlet Obstruction
theory:
Metabolic Derangement

Hypochloremic Metabolic Alkalosis: Vomiting causes loss of HCl (Acid) and Chloride.
Paradoxical Aciduria: The kidney tries to conserve Volume (Na+) at the expense of K+ and H+. In severe dehydration, the kidney excretes H+ into urine despite alkalosis to save Na+.
clinical:
Signs

Succussion Splash: Sloshing sound heard on shaking the patient's abdomen >4 hours after a meal.
Projectile Vomiting: Non-bilious, contains undigested food.
Visible Peristalsis: In thin patients (stomach fighting blockage).
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž Causes
Benign: Pyloric stenosis (scarring from Peptic Ulcer).
Malignant: Antral Gastric Cancer or Pancreatic Head Cancer.

name: Shock & Resuscitation
theory:
Classification

Hypovolemic: Loss of volume (Preload â†“).
Cardiogenic: Pump failure (MI, Arrhythmia).
Obstructive: PE, Tamponade, Tension Pneumothorax.
Distributive: Sepsis, Anaphylaxis (SVR â†“).
clinical:
Resuscitation Priorities

Hypovolemic: Fluid/Blood first. Inotropes are harmful in an 'empty heart'.
Cardiogenic: Inotropes (Dobutamine) + Fluid restriction.
Monitoring: Urine output (>0.5ml/kg/hr) is the best guide to tissue perfusion.
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž ATLS Hemorrhage Classes
Class I: <15% (Normal vitals).
Class II: 15-30% (Tachycardia).
Class III: 30-40% (Hypotension - requires blood).
Class IV: >40% (Lethargic/Anuric).

name: Peri-op Medication Rules
theory:
To Stop

Warfarin: 5 days pre-op (Bridge with Heparin if high risk).
Clopidogrel: 7 days pre-op (platelet life).
COCP/HRT: 4 weeks pre-op (DVT risk).
ACE Inhibitors: 24h pre-op (risk of refractory hypotension).
Oral Hypoglycemics: Day of surgery.
clinical:
To Continue

Beta-blockers: Continue (stopping causes rebound ischemia).
Statins: Continue.
Anticonvulsants: Continue.
Steroids: Continue + give Stress Dose (Hydrocortisone) to prevent Addisonian crisis.
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž Metformin
Stop on day of surgery. If using IV Contrast, hold for 48h post-op to prevent Lactic Acidosis (if AKI occurs).

name: Fistula-in-Ano
theory:
Etiology

Cryptoglandular: Infection of intersphincteric anal glands (90%).
Secondary: Crohn's, TB, Malignancy.

Parks Classification

1. Intersphincteric (45%)
2. Trans-sphincteric (30%)
3. Suprasphincteric
4. Extrasphincteric.
clinical:
Goodsall's Rule

Predicts the track path.
Anterior Opening: Radial straight track to dentate line.
Posterior Opening: Curved track to posterior midline (6 o'clock).
Exception: Anterior openings >3cm from anus may track posteriorly.
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž MRI Pelvis
The gold standard investigation. Essential to map the track relative to the sphincter to prevent incontinence during surgery.

name: Skin Malignancies
theory:
Marjolin's Ulcer

Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC) arising in a chronic wound (burn scar, venous ulcer) after years. Aggressive, mets to nodes.

Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC)

Arises from basal layer. Most common. Locally invasive but almost never metastasizes.
clinical:
Physical Signs

BCC: Pearly nodule, rolled edge, telangiectasia, central scab (Rodent ulcer).
SCC/Marjolin: Everted edge, indurated base, keratin pearls. Painful if Marjolin.
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž Radiotherapy
BCC is radiosensitive (good for face/elderly). Marjolin's (SCC in scar) is radio-resistant and requires wide excision.

name: Flail Chest
theory:
Definition

Fracture of 2 or more adjacent ribs in 2 or more places, creating a floating segment.

Paradoxical Movement

Segment moves in during inspiration and out during expiration (opposite to chest wall).
clinical:
The Real Killer

Hypoxia is caused mainly by the underlying Pulmonary Contusion (bruised lung) and pain-induced hypoventilation (splinting), not just the mechanics.
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž Management Priority
Analgesia (Epidural/Blocks) is crucial to enable breathing. Intubation is reserved for respiratory failure despite analgesia.

name: Intussusception
theory:
Pathology

Telescoping of bowel (usually ileum into colon).
Children: Idiopathic (Peyer's patch hyperplasia post-viral).
Adults: Pathological lead point (Polyp, Tumor, Meckel's) - requires resection.
clinical:
Classic Triad

1. Intermittent colicky pain (screaming, drawing legs up).
2. Redcurrant jelly stool (late sign - mucosal ischemia).
3. Palpable sausage-shaped mass (RUQ) + Empty RIF (Sign of Dance).
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž Target Sign
Ultrasound appearance ('doughnut sign'). First line treatment in kids is Air Enema reduction (unless peritonitis).

name: Varicocele
theory:
Anatomy

Dilatation of pampiniform plexus.
Left Sided (90%): Left testicular vein drains vertically into the high-pressure Renal Vein (Right drains obliquely into IVC).
clinical:
Signs

"Bag of worms" feel. Disappears on lying down. Cough impulse.
Red Flag: Sudden onset left varicocele, or ANY right-sided varicocele = Suspect Renal Tumor (invading renal vein).
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž Infertility
Varicoceles raise scrotal temperature, impairing spermatogenesis. A common treatable cause of male subfertility.

name: Hydronephrosis
theory:
Mechanism

Dilation of renal pelvis/calyces due to obstruction.
Unilateral: Stone, Stricture, TCC ureter.
Bilateral: Bladder outflow obstruction (BPH), Retroperitoneal Fibrosis, Bilateral stones.
clinical:
Dietl's Crisis

Intermittent severe flank pain/nausea after drinking large fluids (in Pelvi-Ureteric Junction Obstruction).

Investigation

USG: First line. CT KUB: For stones.
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž Bilateral Causes
BPH is the most common cause of bilateral hydronephrosis in elderly men. In women, advanced Cervical Ca (frozen pelvis) is a key cause.

name: Keloids vs Hypertrophic Scar
theory:
Keloid

Overgrowth of dense collagen (Type I & III). Extends beyond original wound margins. No spontaneous regression. High recurrence. Genetic/Dark skin predisposition.
clinical:
Hypertrophic Scar

Confined within wound margins. Often regresses/improves with time. Occurs at sites of tension (shoulders/sternum).
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž Treatment
Intralesional Steroids (Triamcinolone). Excision alone has >50% recurrence rate for keloids (must combine with steroids/radiotherapy).

name: Sterilization & Disinfection
theory:
Definitions

Sterilization: Kills ALL organisms + Spores (Autoclave, Ethylene Oxide, Gamma rays).
Disinfection: Reduces load, may not kill spores.
clinical:
Methods

Autoclave (Moist Heat): 121Â°C for 15mins or 134Â°C for 3mins. Best for metal.
Glutaraldehyde (Cidex): High-level disinfectant for Endoscopes (heat sensitive).
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž Skin Prep
Chlorhexidine or Iodine. Iodine is inactivated by organic matter (blood/pus). Chlorhexidine binds to keratin (longer acting).

name: Metabolic Response to Injury
theory:
Phases

Ebb Phase (0-24h): Shock, hypometabolism, conservation.
Flow Phase: Hypermetabolism, catabolism (muscle wasting), insulin resistance, acute phase proteins (CRP).
clinical:
Optimization

1. Analgesia: Blocks stress response.
2. Nutrition: Early enteral feeding attenuates catabolism.
3. Temp: Prevent hypothermia (which worsens coagulopathy).
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž Obligatory Response
The response is physiological and necessary for survival, but harmful if prolonged (SIRS/MODS). It is graded (bigger surgery = bigger response).

name: Inguinal Canal Anatomy
clinical:
Rings

Deep Ring: Mid-inguinal point. Defect = Indirect Hernia.
Superficial Ring: Above pubic tubercle.
Hesselbach's: Medial to Inf Epigastric vessels. Defect = Direct Hernia.
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž Nerves
Ilioinguinal nerve runs ON TOP of the cord, not inside it. Risk of entrapment during repair.

name: Calot's Triangle
theory:
Boundaries

Sup: Liver edge. Med: Common Hepatic Duct. Lat: Cystic Duct.

Contents

Cystic Artery, Lund's Node.
clinical:
Critical View of Safety

Must dissect triangle to identify Cystic Duct and Artery before clipping in Lap Cholecystectomy to avoid CBD injury.
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž Moynihan's Hump
Tortuous Right Hepatic Artery looping into the triangle. Risk of bleeding if mistaken for Cystic Artery.
